Abstract: This autobiographical account chronicles the journey of a pioneering woman scientist in the field of visual perception. The narrative explores her groundbreaking research in psychophysics, focusing on color vision, hyperacuity, stereopsis, trajectory motion, and amblyopia. Through personal anecdotes and scientific insights, the author reflects on the challenges and triumphs of her career, highlighting the evolving landscape for women in science. The memoir not only showcases significant contributions to visual neuroscience but also serves as an inspiration for aspiring researchers, particularly women, in the scientific community. By interweaving personal experiences with scientific discoveries, this work provides a unique perspective on the intersection of gender, science, and perseverance in academia.
